articles.headline: In Shift, Accord on North Korea Seems to Be Set
articles.snippet: The tentative agreement calls for North Korea to start disabling its nuclear facilities and to allow inspectors back in exchange for fuel oil and aid.
articles.abstract: The tentative agreement calls for North Korea to start disabling its nuclear facilities and to allow inspectors back in exchange for fuel oil and aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Tuesday, Feb. 13 — The United States and four other nations reached a tentative agreement to provide North Korea with roughly $400 million in fuel oil and aid, in return for the North’s starting to disable its nuclear facilities and allowing nuclear inspectors back into the country, according to American officials who have reviewed the proposed text.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: West Adds to Strains on Iran’s Lifeline
articles.snippet: The world’s fourth-largest oil exporter is forced to import 40 percent of its gasoline because of sanctions and booming consumption.
articles.abstract: The world’s fourth-largest oil exporter is forced to import 40 percent of its gasoline because of sanctions and booming consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: Western political and economic pressure on Iran over its nuclear program has chilled foreign investment to the extent that it is now squeezing the country’s long-fragile energy industry, adding strains to a government that is burdened by sanctions and wary of unrest at home.

articles.headline: One Year Later, Golden Mosque Is Still in Ruins
articles.snippet: In the year since insurgents ripped a hole in one of Iraq’s most sacred Shiite shrines, there has been no rebuilding and no healing.
articles.abstract: In the year since insurgents ripped a hole in one of Iraq’s most sacred Shiite shrines, there has been no rebuilding and no healing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAMARRA, Iraq, Feb. 11 — It has been a year since Sunni insurgents ripped a hole in the glorious dome here of one of Iraq’s most sacred Shiite shrines, shattering its 72,000 golden tiles and unleashing a tide of national sectarian bloodletting. Not a single brick of the mosque has been moved since.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Curtail Investor Suits
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission is promoting a legal standard that would make it harder for shareholders to win fraud lawsuits against companies and executives.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is promoting a legal standard that would make it harder for shareholders to win fraud lawsuits against companies and executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun to take steps on two fronts to protect corporations, executives and accounting firms from investor lawsuits that accuse them of fraud.

articles.headline: States and U.S. at Odds on Aid for Uninsured
articles.snippet: In the absence of federal action, governors and state legislators are transforming the health care system.
articles.abstract: In the absence of federal action, governors and state legislators are transforming the health care system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  In the absence of federal action, governors and state legislators around the country are transforming the nation’s health care system, putting affordable health insurance within reach of millions of Americans in hopes of reversing the steady rise in the number of uninsured, now close to 47 million.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Raymond Hernandez

articles.headline: This Expansion Looks Familiar
articles.snippet: Many forecasters are worried that the latest economic expansion is running out of steam, just as workers have finally begun to reap some of the spoils.
articles.abstract: Many forecasters are worried that the latest economic expansion is running out of steam, just as workers have finally begun to reap some of the spoils.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is five years into an economic expansion and most Americans are still waiting for their share. Inflation is swallowing pay raises. Businesses are hiring, but forecasters worry that the economy may be about to stall.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Skeptics Doubt U.S. Evidence on Iran Action in Iraq
articles.snippet: The response speaks to U.S. credibility four years after the intelligence controversy leading up to the Iraq war.
articles.abstract: The response speaks to U.S. credibility four years after the intelligence controversy leading up to the Iraq war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 — Three weeks after promising it would show proof of Iranian meddling in Iraq, the Bush administration has laid out its evidence — and received in return a healthy dose of skepticism.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Home Depot May Shed Unit to Focus on Retail
articles.snippet: The company announced a move that, if completed, would be a sharp rebuke of the strategy of the former chief executive Robert L. Nardelli.
articles.abstract: The company announced a move that, if completed, would be a sharp rebuke of the strategy of the former chief executive Robert L. Nardelli.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Robert L. Nardelli was deposed as chief executive of Home Depot, several of the country’s biggest buyout firms welcomed the company’s new leader, Frank Blake, with a tantalizing proposal, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: J.& J. Says Improper Payments Were Made
articles.snippet: Johnson & Johnson said  it believed that some of its foreign units had made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries.
articles.abstract: Johnson & Johnson said  it believed that some of its foreign units had made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson, the drug and consumer products company, said last night that some of its foreign units might have made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two “small-market countries.”
